did.unittitle: Collection of Tract Maps and Cadastral Maps of Southern California
did.abstract: The tract and cadastral maps in this collection are of real estate developments located in Los Angeles, Orange, Riverside and Ventura counties. The maps are listed by location using the Thomas Brothers Maps' Los Angeles County Popular Street Atlas, 1931 and Orange County, 1981. A few maps fall outside of this territory, and for these, relevant leaves of the Thomas ... Riverside County, 1978, and Ventura County, 1979, have been included.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

dao.xlink:title: Tract Maps and Cadastral Maps of Southern California (9 items)

daodesc.p: Tract Maps and Cadastral Maps of Southern California (9 items)

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: Property rights to the physical objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Collection of Tract Maps and Cadastral Maps of Southern California (Collection Number 349). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by UCLA Library Special Collections staff.

Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Potentially Offensive Description in Library Special Collections.

bioghist.head: History
bioghist.p: Tract maps present certain problems in indexing or cataloging since they do not all have a common element such as a name or a cartographer. The approach, therefore, that seems most logical is to list the maps by location. The locator used by the Cadastral Map Collection is the Thomas Brothers Maps' Los Angeles County Popular Street Atlas, 1931 and Orange County, 1981. A few maps fall outside of this territory, and for these, eleven leaves of the Thomas ... Riverside County, 1978, and Ventura County, 1979, have been included. The location is designated by atlas page number and grid coordinates (the area where the letters printed across the top of the page intersect the numbers printed down the side). This location designation has been used as the call number of individual maps.

There are various ways of approaching this collection. If the name of a tract is known, it is listed alphabetically in the finding aid. In addition, there are chronological and location (call) number lists. Few maps have all of these elements. If the location of the tract map is all that is known, the Thomas Atlas must be checked to find a location designation. The finding aid must then be consulted to see if a map exists for that location.

When more than one tract appears on a map, each tract has been given its own location designation. The first such location designation has been used for the call number and all other tracts have bee cited with a see reference to that number.
Where information about the owner or realtor is available, it has been included in the finding aid.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Collection consists of tract and cadastral maps of real estate developments, some projected but never realized, located in Los Angeles and vicinity. Most tracts are located in Los Angeles and Orange counties, but some are in Riverside and Ventura counties. Tracts are listed alphabetically, chronologically, and by location (call) number in the finding aid.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection is arranged alphabetically by name of tract.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: A Collection of Tract Maps From a Real Estate Business Scrapbook, Los Angeles (Collection 295) . Available at the UCLA Library Special Collections.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: The Thomas Brothers Map of Los Angeles County, 1981 is to be used in conjunction with this finding aid.

altformavail.head: Online Items Available
altformavail.p: Portions of this collection have been digitized and are available online: Tract Maps and Cadastral Maps of Southern California (9 items).

odd.head: General
odd.p: THE MACLAY RANCHO Ex Mission of San Fernando. Trustees: H. L. Macneil, Geo. C. Hagar, C Maclay, J. K. Alexander, R. M. Widney. NOTE: The Blocks numbered from 1 to 402 are divided into four(40 parts by lines runnning parallel to the Streets. These parts are known as the North, East, West and South subdivisions or ___Acres, and are so described in the Deeds.
R. M. Widney, et al., Trustees, University Bank 317 New High Street, Los Angeles, Cal.
